image.altText: A man in a green army jacket sits in a wheelchair in a clearing in a wood

props.synopsis: An officer who led his troops into one of the key initial battles of Ukraine's counteroffensive labels the operation a failure.

title.children: This Ukrainian commander says leaks, fearsome choppers and poor planning doomed the counteroffensive

image.altText: Flooding in a regional area in the low light of dawn.

props.synopsis: More than 300 millimetres of rain has fallen on the New South Wales South Coast and emergency services are preparing for another day of wet conditions.

title.children: Flooding in NSW, more rain to come as waterway swells by more than 1m in a night

image.altText: A woman lying in bed blowing her nose with a tissue.

props.synopsis: After NSW Premier Chris Minns contracted the virus this week, he strongly recommended people stay at home until their COVID symptoms subside. Here's what the experts say.

title.children: Here's how long to self-isolate for if you develop COVID symptoms amid Christmas peak concerns

image.altText: A shot of a busy Melbourne street with pedestrians in front of a tram.

props.synopsis: The record-breaking level of migration triggers a public debate around its impact on Australia's inflation problem and a full-blown rental crisis.Â

title.children: Is the record level of migration fuelling inflation and the rental crisis?

image.altText: A supercell over Queensland

props.synopsis: Supercells are the biggest and baddestÂ kind of severe thunderstorm, capable of producing violent winds, large hail, and tornadoes.

title.children: What is a supercell thunderstorm and why is it so dangerous?

image.altText: A young person holding a small dog and standing outside between two armed men wearing balaclavas, standing near cars.

props.synopsis: For the first time since the truce began, both sides of the war trade accusations of serious ceasefire violations. Follow live.Â

title.children: Israel and Hamas accuse each other of ceasefire violations, as more prisoners and hostages are released

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: There are hopes for a second extension to the temporary ceasefire
Israel and Hamas release more people as part of ceasefire deal
Ceasefire appears to hold, despite both sides accusing each other of breaches

image.altText: Chief Minister of the state of Uttarakhand, greeting a worker rescued.

props.synopsis: The 41 workers, trapped for 17 days inside a collapsed tunnel in India's Uttarakhand state, were freed one at a time on wheeled stretchers through a pipe 90cm wide.

title.children: After 17 days trapped all 41 Indian tunnel workers are rescued

image.altText: Woman in a white and red printed shirt next to a young man in a light pink shirt at an outdoor bar.

props.synopsis: Hersh Goldberg-Polin was abducted by HamasÂ at the Supernova music festival in southern Israel. His mother is desperate for news about his welfare.

title.children: 'We're turning over every stone': Rachel Goldberg's battle to find her abducted son

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann walks into court.

props.synopsis: Bruce Lehrmann has now been on the stand for four days being questioned about the night Brittany Higgins alleges she was raped and the media coverage which followed it.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann tells court he believes Brittany Higgins's fiance sent him threatening email titled 'Coming for you'

image.altText: A screencap of CCTV footage showing the moment a bus started moving towards a petrol station at Casino, NSW.

props.synopsis: The 14-year-old girl from Casino High School, who was sitting on the bus with about 20 others, sprung into action when she noticed it moving without anybody in the driver's seat, narrowly preventing what could have been a major disaster.

title.children: Quick thinking teenage girl saves runaway bus from crashing into New South Wales petrol station

image.altText: A woman peers to the side in front of a window wearing a black shirt

props.synopsis: As survivors of alleged historical physical and sexual abuse at the hands of foster carers in the Northern Territory seek justice, they say they are battling significant delays and distressÂ akin to "being abused again".Â

title.children: Mary was repeatedly abused as a child in the foster care system. She's among dozens of survivors battling for justice

image.altText: Woman wearing face mask

props.synopsis: While it's probably no surprise that governments spent billions of dollars fighting COVID-19, new data analysis shows how much Australians spent during the first three years of the pandemic.Â

title.children: The countries that spent more on fighting COVID than Australia â but with worse results

image.altText: People walk in the snow.

props.synopsis: Finland will close even its most remote border crossing with Russia, drawing a line in the Arctic snow, as it looks to stop asylum seekers flooding in from Russia.

title.children: Finland draws line in Arctic snow, closing entire border with Russia

image.altText: Jim Chalmers stands in a courtyard at parliament house.

props.synopsis: Many of us don't trust politicians, but surely politicians ought to trust politicians? History shows why they might one day need to overturn a Reserve Bank decision, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: The government is about to try to remove a crucial veto power it has over the Reserve Bank. It may not be so wise

image.altText: Close-up of man

props.synopsis: The court decision comes after the former SAS soldier's civil case against Nine Entertainment was dismissed in June, prompting a complicated battle over legal costs.

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith ordered to pay indemnity costs for entirety of his failed defamation case

image.altText: Pat Cummins smiling during an interview.

props.synopsis: Since taking over the Australian cricket captaincy, Pat Cummins has been outspoken on social issues, sparking backlash and claims from critics that he had become "too woke". But he says he feels emboldened by the negative responses.

title.children: 'I know who I am': Pat Cummins on refusing to pander to a 'loud minority'

image.altText: A man is wearing a cricket helmet while holding a cricket bat with two hands.

props.synopsis: Australia pulls off a miraculous win against India, with Glenn Maxwell dragging the team to its first victory of the series.

title.children: Australia chases down mammoth Indian total thanks to record-equalling Glenn Maxwell century

image.altText: An older woman with a dark grey bob and glasses speaks into a small microphone in front of a blue screen.

props.synopsis: The RBA's Michele Bullock says households are "doing fine" while speaking on a panel in Hong Kong last night. Follow live.Â

title.children: RBA's governor says Australians 'doing fine' as households ponder another rate hike

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: What the RBA's governor said in Hong Kong last night

image.altText: Ukraine's Military Intelligence chief Kyrylo Budanov and his wife Marianna.

props.synopsis: Marianna Budanova,Â an advisor to Kyiv mayor Vitali Klitschko, was allegedly poisoned with substances "not used in normal life or military affairs".

title.children: Wife of Ukraine intelligence chief in hospital after alleged assassination attempt

image.altText: Olemedia Books AI Brain

props.synopsis: Training AI models on copyrighted materials has led to an array of high-profile lawsuits against developers such as OpenAI and Meta. Can the models be "untrained" or is the genie out of the bottle?

title.children: 'The law is light-years behind': The battle over training AI on copyrighted work

image.altText: 18-year-old autistic student Connor Winfield studies at a computer.

props.synopsis: Experts and students with lived experience warn that mainstream classrooms are critically underprepared to educate Australia's expanding cohort of autistic students.

title.children: Mainstream Australian classrooms 'not prepared' to educate the expanding cohort of autistic students

image.altText: Matildas players cheer reacting to a penalty shoot out in a large stadium

props.synopsis: The government will introduce laws to keep more content accessible on free-to-air television, and place Australian networks on a level pegging with streaming platforms on smart television home screens.

title.children: New laws to prevent 'iconic' sport moments slipping behind paywalls

image.altText: An older lady wearing a life jacket holds a blue flag that reads, RISING TIDE.

props.synopsis: The latest blockade of the Port of Newcastle is the crest of a wave that started building back in 2005 for the climate group behind the protest, Rising Tide.Â

title.children: How an idea floated almost 20 years ago became one of nation's biggest climate-action blockades

image.altText: Woman in a white and blue dress with her hands on her hips standing next to a man in a black t-shirt.

props.synopsis: Gus Kuster was being held in indefinite detention until three weeks ago. Now released and fitted with a monitoring ankle bracelet, he says he still doesn't feel free.

title.children: Gus has been released from detention and fitted with an ankle bracelet. He wants you to know his story

image.altText: High Court of Australia

props.synopsis: Responding to the full reasons of the High Court published on Tuesday, the home affairs minister says the government is finalising a "preventative detention regime" for detainees who were ordered released from indefinite immigration detention.

title.children: Government to introduce 'tough' preventative detention for detainees released by High Court order

image.altText: An employee of DP World walking along the Melbourne wharves

props.synopsis: After a cyber attack shut down Australia's largest ports operator earlier in November, DP World Australia has confirmed that current and former employees have had their data stolen by an unidentified third party.

title.children: DP World confirms personal employee data was stolen during cyber attack

image.altText: The cover of Sports Illustrated Super Bowl LVII commemorative issue.

props.synopsis: American magazine Sports Illustrated denies it used content created by artificial intelligence after it was accused of publishing articles by fake authors with AI-generated headshots.

title.children: 'This person does not exist': Sports Illustrated magazine denies using AI-generated authors for website content

image.altText: Tree branch through headrest

props.synopsis: A group of girls were returning to their accommodation along one of K'gari's sand tracks when a tree branch smashed the windscreen and speared through a passenger seat headrest.

title.children: Schoolies group lucky to be alive after tree branch smashes through windscreen

image.altText: Doctor administers intravenous line into a patient's arm

props.synopsis: There are at least 43 suspected cases of Ralstonia in Australia, and an elderly patient'sÂ death at a private hospital on the Sunshine Coast is also believed to be linked. Here's what you need to know.

title.children: Dozens of infections and one death linked to contaminated saline. What is Ralstonia and how dangerous is it?

image.altText: People walk past an Optus store in Sydney.

props.synopsis: In written answers to Senate questions on notice, Optus has confirmed it has paid compensation in cash to customers affected by its nationwide outage on November 8, after being slammed for originally only offering extra data.

title.children: Optus begins compensating customers with cash over nationwide outage after earlier offer of extra data

image.altText: A boy and his dad smiling together while on a mountain.

props.synopsis: Federal and state parliament pay tribute to Charlie Stevens, the son of SA's police commissioner, as well as police officer Brevet Sargent Jason Doig.

title.children: 'Beloved heart of a universe': Charlie Stevens eulogised by prime minister as opposition leader breaks down

image.altText: A bushwalker stands in button grass with eyes closed and smiles in the sun

props.synopsis: This YouTuber and Instagram adventure filmmaker was threatened with fines over his treks into Tasmania's wilderness areas. Now, he has been issued with a new "commercial filming licence" applicationÂ â which he says he'll ignore because the strict conditions will kill his business.

title.children: Instagram adventurer won't abide by rules on filming in Tasmanian wilderness areas
